posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
What are y’all’s favorite sensors for beam-break/presence that work in direct sun?

I love the ~$5 Amazon IR sensors, but they fail with moderate amounts of interference. https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B0CQZX3N52/ref=ox_sc_act_title_1?smid=ATCVC199CHVK0&psc=1

We switched to CANRange this year with the hope that the distance sensing package would not be affected by generic sunlight interference, but found out this summer that actually we still can’t run automation that depends on the “presence” thresholding outdoors. (They do tend to operate ok under a canopy at least.)

Has anyone found a single-sided beam break or presence sensor that’ll handle full sunlight interference well? Have you found a two sided (emitter/receiver) solution that works for full sun?

link_counts.title: NOYITO E3F-DS30P1 Proximity Switch Photoelectric Sensor Switch 30cm Adjustable Detection Distance Diffuse Reflection Infrared Switch DC 6-36V 3-Wire PNP NO: Amazon.com: Industrial & Scientific

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked:
I wonder if ultrasonic range sensors would be acceptable for your application, since they won’t  affected by sunlight.

If you really need to use optical sensors, I would try using laser based sensors (probably beam break instead of LIDAR), with a shroud around the emmiter/receiver.

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: I’m not sure how good the pricey banner ones that are also in first choice are about the sun, but they might be an option. Worth looking into. You could also cause a massive volcanic eruption, triggering an ash cloud that blocks out the sun.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
We’ve had really good experiences with these AutomationDirect beam breaks. They’re a bit pricey, but fairly immune to outside light interference (we’ve never had any issues with them, even on outdoor demos). I think the way the receivers lens is designed makes it more directional than other sensors, thus making it more tolerant to light bouncing from other sources… or something like that. The only downside is you have to do a little creative wiring to use them since they require 12v power delivery.

I find that “Visible Red” line break sensors like these tend to be far more reliable than IR-based sensors or photoreflective sensors. We’ve used the CANRange quite a bit this year as well and have been happy with it, though our implementation is not quite as ambient-light sensitive (it’s somewhat enclosed, and very short-range).

Any optical sensor is going to have a limit to how much ambient light it can handle before the sensor is “dazzled” (like if you’ve ever been blinded walking out from a dark room into bright sunlight). You can mitigate this with “shielding” (blocking out at least some ambient light), using a physical contact sensor instead (like a limit switch), or possibly even ultrasonic sensors (though those are also prone to different types of interference).

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
I see your point about ultrasonic physics working better, and I’ve also just never seen the Maxbotics as a Production quality device. Probably because most of the ones I’ve used are in their fifth or tenth or fiftieth “my first sensor feedback” workshop iteration and getting a bit worse for the wear from repeated use by new engineers in training…

cbale2000:

require 12v power delivery.

Like nice regulated 12v? I wouldn’t mind sticking a tiny regulator next to it, we run battery power everywhere already.

Tell me more about how you’re avoiding dazzle on your CANRange? Ours is high on the robot mounted to clear polycarbonate and looking at more clear polycarbonate, so there is definitely currently many ways for lots of ambient light to arrive at it…

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
It’s 10v-30v tolerant, so it’s not required, but a regulator also never hurts. Technically since it’s an NPN “photoswitch” I also read somewhere that you need to add a certain resistor to the circuit to make it so the RoboRIO can detect it properly over DIO, but we always just wired them to the analog inputs and set the threshold voltage manually.

For dazzle prevention, basically the thing to remember is that if a CANRange isn’t seeing the bounce-back from the laser, the range reading is essentially “infinity”, in the use-case of a presence (game piece, usually) detector, we really only care that the sensor can see the reflection of the laser when the object it’s trying to detect is there. To that end, reducing the distance between the object and the sensor as much as possible (within the minimum limits of the sensor) helps a lot. After that, you just have to consider ways to reduce the light that’s getting in between the thing you’re trying to detect and the sensor.

If you were dealing with a polycarbonate intake, one method might be to use smoked polycarbonate or even something as simple as a sharpie or some non-clear tape to block light from entering. You don’t need to create a perfect black-out seal or anything, just reduce the total luminance so the laser can shine through it.

One other thing we did on our polycarbonate intake was design it with a hole for the sensor to see though (the CANRange should have an unobstructed view, don’t shine it through poly if possible), and then took a sharpie to the inside edges of the hole (with the sensor removed) to blacken it. Clear plastics can act a bit like a fiber optic cable and transmit light in every direction through them, creating a kind of glow that can affect sensors (acrylic does this best, but poly does too, to a degree).

Lastly, make sure your CANRange is set to “ Short Range ” detection mode for best results.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
Our solution is to recess the sensor or 3d print a small circular ‘cowl’ (out of mat black filament) to place directly around the receive side of the sensor.  We also engineer the solutions to never look “up”, always down.  This seems to have solved our issues, even with the more sensitive sensors.

Another item to consider is to make sure that the surfaces on the opposite side from he sensor are not reflective.  We often throw some black gaffers tape to prevent indirect reflections of bright lights.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
We used Maxbotixs extensively, wayyyyyy back in 2008-2011.  What we found was that for ‘real time’ sensing, it was simply not accurate or fast enough.  To obtain an accurate measurement relied on significant filtering because of fluctuations in the returned signal.  The filtering added into the 20hz response rate was simply to slow for what we wanted (monitoring distance from the wall real time as we drove toward it).  I’m not sure what the current state of the sensor library is, but the return signal is also non-linear, and you needed to use a formula or create a regression to change the returned signal into a human readable distance.  Between adjusting the regression formula, the signal filtering, and the read time, it wasn’t what we wanted.

All those combined together led us away from the Maxbotics and toward faster sensors - the Garmin style laser sensor worked well for us for real-time fast distance monitoring.

Now, we just use one of the many can-enabled laser rangefinders on the market.

posts.name: Chris LaSalle
posts.cooked:
Try this

Price: USD 45

This device can sense position or color. We used it last season to sense coral in our end effector.

posts.name: Bryce Roethel
posts.cooked:
Zatack7:

I’m not sure how good the pricey banner ones that are also in first choice are about the sun, but they might be an option. Worth looking into.

340 has been using these sensors from Banner for years and has had great success with them. It utilizes a polarized reflective target which makes the sensor more resilient to light pollution. We’ve ran them outside for demos and haven’t experienced any problems.

IMG_1073 1052×894 161 KB

IMG_1073 1052×894 161 KB

IMG_1073 1052×894 161 KB

A different sensor from Banner is typically offered in the KoP with the required cable, which we usually request. The sensor does require a regulated input voltage, we typically power it through the VRM .

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked: We used the lasercan this year, and in testing saw with my phones light directly on the sensor or totally blocking light around it, it had no trouble detecting notes.

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked:
Dominick_Ferone:

and in testing saw with my phones light directly on the sensor

I don’t think IR would affect the lasercan, but it is worth noting that your phone’s flashlight emits basically no IR.
